Dear Sir, We enclose herewith copy of a letter we have today addressed to the Manager, Cable & Wireless Ltd., Bahrein, from which you will see our firm are contemplating the introduction of light portable speech transmitting and receiving sets so that we may keep in touch with our sub branches on the Arabian Coast. Before we could operate these transmitters and receivers we presume it would be necessary to obtain the sanction of the Governments concerned and we should be glad to have your views and advice as to how we should proceed in this matter. Dear Sir, You are no doubt aware that much of our work, especially in connection with lighterage business, is conducted at or with such outlying places as Has Tanura, AlKhobar and Zekrit anti it is probable that in the near future we shall also be operating at Ras el Mishaao* There are no means of. communicating with these points by civilian telegraphs and it is important that we should be in constant touch with our staff at these various places. We have had under consideration for some time the question of improving our means of communication with automatic transmitters and receivers. Our Head office in London inform us that such equipment is available as surplus Government stores. They inform us that one of the essential conditions for the use of such instruments is that they can be used on a frequency within a range of service material. The Political Agent, Bahrein* Dear Sir, Bahrein, 20th si 19 We refer to our letter L/206 of the 6th instant regarding the proposal to instal radio telephone sets to enable us to establish direct coraraunication between our office at Manama and such points as Ras Tanura, Al Khobar, Zekrit and Mishaab. As Lloyd*s agents we are required to cable Lloyds, London, daily the movements of vessels at Bahrein and at Ras Tanura. Since there are no civil Post and Telegraphic communications with Ras Tanura we are obliged to rely on the Arabian American Oil Co* for advice of arrivals a nd departures of shipping at Ras Tanura, but although we have impressed on them the importance of our receiving such information promptly it is not infrequently several days old before it reaches us* In this connection Lloyds London have written us on the date 10.7*47 as follows M With regard to reports covering Ras Tanura, we have noticed that the information telegraphed by you covering that port is frequently several days old* Is it possible that your Sub-Agents at that port could also telegraph direct to this Office without incurring the delay of transmitting the information to you? It should be strongly emphasised to them that telegrams to be of value should be sent without delay, otherwise no advantage is gained in incurring the expense of telegraphic transmission. I shall be glad to hear from you in this connection as soon as possible M . If we could have our own means of direct communication with our office at Ras Tanura we would be able to obtain prompt advice of the arrivals and departures of shipping at that port, and so would be able to pass it on to Lloyds London without the delay at present experienced. No doubt we shall later be required to advise shipping movements at Mishaab also, and this alone may be considered by the authorities concerned as sufficient to warrant our being permitted to instal radio telephone sets. lb •#•*••**Gray, Mackenzie & Co. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 13; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 3-11; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file discusses a proposal by Gray, Mackenzie and Company Limited to introduce portable wireless transmitting sets in order to keep in touch with their various branches on the Arabian coast of the Persian Gulf.A series of file notes which were maintained as a record of the correspondence in the volume can be found at folio 11. These file notes include background on Gray Mackenzie's use of Radio Telegraph during the second world war and similar prior requests from other companies which were denied.
